@HelmAtCAN Yup. All of this. I'm simultaneously grateful I wasn't pathologized into the 1990s understanding of ADHD and autism, but I also grieve what the ableism of that era's diagnostic criteria and "treatments" cost me in terms of real understanding of myself.

Without a diagnosis, yes, it protected me from the awful interventions of "special education," especially in rural Virginia.

But it also meant they didn't know how to anticipate how I would be exploited. They couldn't protect me.

And I thus never learned how to protect myself.

My parents valued my difference a lot of the time. I was still judged harshly for some of the features of my neurodivergence. They just thought I was weird. 

But they also had no idea how to protect me from all the people (especially, in my exp, older men) who took advantage.

I think neurotypical folks don't understand how traumatizingly anti-neurodivergent the world is.

I had a good childhood. Not problem free, but my parents loved and provided for me in really substantial ways. (Still do)

Yet my childhood involved repeated victimization & trauma.

My dad: I don't really recall you stimming as a child.

Me, figuring out I'm autistic at 30: I literally sucked my thumb until I was 12 to the point that thumb is still shaped differently from the other.

@EdDevTrevor @AnnGagne This. Trying to hold myself accountable. I struggle with adhd impulsivity that means I forget to check (settling for imperfect activism you know) but I’m trying to commit to intentionality, especially as my small platform grows. You’re the voice I hear when I consider retweeting!

But the texture of label & smooth plastic in my palm as I count mouthfuls of medicines that give me life remind me I have a choice to give myself life too. And this act of taking, of swallowing, of being present in the counting, ordering, naming, is life work. And love in motion.

I have a decade of CBT & medical gaslighting to heal. It taught me to ignore, as much as possible, the truth my body spoke to me in the form of pain.

I still rely on it every day.

And that forgetting lets me pretend I can do more than I can and judge myself cruelly when I fail.

Pathologize me, but my daily rituals around my medication are some of the most important & grounding labor I do.

I take 12+ daily medications to manage life threatening illnesses.

My ritual reminds me of the stakes, the tremendous accomplishment of caring for this sacred body.

All bodyminds deserve to live in their wholeness and brokenness in peace. And maybe gentleness toward ourselves can translate into gentleness to others here. This crip humour isn’t bad, but is it possible to be more intentional so it doesn’t imperil others’ and our own softness?

I know this bc I’ve felt it. When I was navigating coming out as a genderqueer femme, I had to unfollow people who navigated this exploration with self deprecating humour. This doesn’t make that humour wrong.

But perhaps we can be more intentional with where we say it & to whom.

And these times, there is a small voice in our heads that says “I should believe that this is wrong about my bodymind. That I should hate it too. That this thing is not covered by crip love and acceptance. That this is truly broken and not welcome in our future liberation.”

I’m learning the to be more careful with my self deprecation. Sometimes it’s connection -seeking behavior. I need folks to tell me no, I’m not bad.

Other times it’s a genuine joke but said in hearing of people whose self love is far more wounded by a lifetime of ableist violence

But the severe anxiety these high-stakes tasks create when I am in the unproductive but organized mode is absolutely devastating.

I have struggled mightily in academia, however, to find any other way of operating simply bc of the structure of the place.

This is why I take on too many high-stakes tasks. The stress built into them is fuel for my ADHD, albeit fuel that also consumes other parts of my body in order to burn. But having lots of seemingly very important tasks to bounce btwn in the chaos makes me effective on some.

I have only two modes:
-Highly organized and unproductive
-Absolute chaos and hyperproductive.

I can either organize my life and do absolutely none of the tasks I organized. Or I can descend into my innate chaos and get something done. What will I get done? Who the fuck knows.

And honour the discomfort of our fellows on this earth whose ancestral/lived trauma spill from the violence of our power.

They get to call us out. They get to rage. They get to point at our wound and say “see?”

These are transformative times. Let’s be transformed, too./fin

It is okay to be moved, horrified, terrified in new ways that feel alien but bizarrely familiar. It is okay to be unable to look away.

But you have to remember this feeling, the ancestral energy vibrating in you, & ✨use it✨ for others unlike you.

Be moved. Be changed./10

I have felt like this only a handful of times in my life, yet my country, from whom I derive material benefit, security, and stability, ✨even as a Mad disabled queer✨, has invaded all but 3 countries on the planet (at highest count)./9

Non-white, poor, or non-Christian people around the world ✨have this ancestral unease evoked all the time.✨ Often, imperial/colonial violence, the massive catastrophe of the US/Euro/Russia/Israel generally existing, is so violent there is not time for it to become ancestral./8

But this feeling? The discomfort,how enthralled we are, unable to look away, is based in white privilege.

We can claim legacies of trauma in our ancestry & current lives.

But we also must see how white privilege allows us to forget this legacy most of the time. /7

I am reverberating with a memory of an enormous world power bearing down on my kin. I am remembering that, in a way. And it is disorienting, and it explains some of why the world “cares” more for the Ukraine than literally any non-white country on earth facing mass violence. /6

The 20th century displaced many European families around the world.

Many arrived with the trauma in hand. Many of us, their descendants, continue to reverberate with it.

That said, *all* of my family arrived and created wealth from settler colonialism and racial capitalism./5

I mentioned how I felt, as the people of Ukraine face the astounding power of Russian military might, as though my body was remembering something. I could sense an elusive, blurred memory. Perhaps epigenetics, perhaps cosmic, perhaps from having loved the refugees of my family./3

I spoke to my dad this morning about my Opa, a refugee from Germany in the embroiled years of the Weimar Republic and Hitler’s rise to power. My Irish, Scottish, and Czech families also all fled enormous violence and war in Europe to North America. Many in the 20th cent. /2

A thread thinking through ancestral memory, crisis in Ukraine, and white euro privilege:

Disclaimer: I am thinking through this, open to critique, and write this as one of many answers.

@GraysonGoal @yxscuh @cathycrea Yes. It requires a LOT of self knowledge and work to understand how our rights are or are not guaranteed. That said, asking fellow disabled people for help (especially through social media; maybe #NEISvoid even) can help you wade through some of this.

All of this is to say, if you choose not to register w disability services or they deny your accommodations, or you're just too exhausted to get to it yet, this has no bearing on whether you're disabled enough or at all. With or without documentation, you have a right to access.

By disability justice standards, accommodations should not exist, esp as they do. Community, collective access is what's required. Individual approaches can *never* guarantee nondisabled levels of access in higher education.

They are a tool, for now, that I hope eventually die.

You may luck out with a prof all about UDL or even a fellow crip. Most often, you find people who think they're "inclusive" but are invested in having paper documentation and individual access fixes.

Then there are the assholes where it makes no diff if you've got documentation.

While the in both Canada and the US there are laws governing university disability policy, functional access varies DRASTICALLY from university to university.

These policies, too, are not designed for access. They function to protect the university from litigation.

All this is to say that YOU get to choose whether or not you register with disability services at your university. I have and it has been both useful and a hindrance.

You should talk with other disabled students, get the vibe of the office, and see exactly what it might give you

(as an aside: I actually find a lot of Indigenous scholarship tremendously valuable here for thinking through the "politics of recognition" like Coulthard's Red Skins, White Masks, linked below.) https://t.co/IspkeUrkyV

The process also exposes us to tremendous anti-disabled rhetoric and violence. We are exposed to a system that determines our worthiness to take up space in the university by norms and rules not our own. Not the community's or the individual's.

The work of registering, too, is expensive and labour/time intensive. Learning assessments expire. Bloodwork, doctors letters, medical records are only valid for many conditions for an arbitrary period.

The fees pile up--paperwork, consultations, testing, etc.

After what we've learned about Harvard this week (school counselors aiding in forcing marg. students out), this is particularly concerning.

Yes. Privacy laws protect those records.

Privacy laws enforced by people employed by my university & employer.

The risk remains.

Disclosure is fraught. I am deeply uncomfortable with how I have had to hand over analyses of my literal DNA to my university to secure even a toe-hold here. My psychiatric records are housed at my university (who is also my employer.

I think many of us "elder" crip academics know this, but I want to say explicitly that disabled students do NOT have to register with disability services. 

(a short thread thinking through disability services after Harvard revelations)

@yxscuh @cathycrea @GraysonGoal But also, disability services won't solve everything. I wish it were otherwise, that you didn't have to self advocate, but choosing rest and care for your body when it's screaming that it needs it is essential. Hard, complicated, not without risk, but also the sustainable choice.

@yxscuh @cathycrea @GraysonGoal This is all very, very hard. It's okay to have "not gotten to it yet." Disabled students have to do three to four times the bureaucratic and academic work with a fraction of the resources.

A trauma response is often, especially for marginalized people, a response to the overwhelming violence that surrounds them every day.

Healing requires collectivity, community, organized for our safety./3

Trauma is one of those words we use without really sitting with its meaning.

I don’t think it’s overused.

Unskilled is a lie.

I often say my pedagogy is simple: I want my students to leave unharmed. This is very very hard at times, but entirely possible.

It’s bc I care first. I care about what I teach & who I teach it to. Teaching is relational. It is a tremendous privilege and responsibility./7

/6

I love Jane Nicholas on this.

As educators, what harm are we recreating in displaying past vulnerability esp in mixed spaces of beneficiaries & descendants of those harmed? /5

A reaction, tho, is not necessarily care/caring. /4

Initially, it made me realize trigger warnings are essential accessibility mechanisms. I’ve spent literal *years* recovering from that flare up of my CPTSD.

Later, tho, I realized: We shouldn’t just avoid triggering students. We need to avoid *being the initial trauma, too.*/3

Maybe this is controversial. I have found myself justifying every dollar I spend, though, both to nondisabled & disabled voices & I’m tired.

If I give you funds, you never have to justify how you use it to me. I ask the same. No receipts. Never transactional. Only care. /fin

Mutual aid refuses charity’s approach of justification/documentation. It doesn’t ask for receipts. We give to enable life—incl joy, richness, and yes, even frivolity. Not just meds.

Crip solidarity means mutual responsibility. Trust one another. Remember our obligations, too./3

Sometimes I think we forget that just because we give one another money, passing it around between us, that doesn’t make us privy to people’s spending. They have sovereignty of bodymind, and if they said they needed the money, they needed it.

Mutual aid is not charity. /2

One of the things I wish we stopped doing as crip community is policing one another’s expenses and spending. Refuse to surveil one another. An enormous form of state violence so many of us experience is enforced poverty and state interference in our spending. Trust one another./1

Our desires to nurture, parent, mother, father, sustain the future of our children, especially, for me, children who are like me, whose futures are seen as impossible or undesireable, is good. We are allowed it.

And we also do not deserve to be abandoned for choosing it. /fin

This is a grief thread. I put it here so I can lay my shame down & see it as the grief & fear & anger that it is. None of this is shameful.
And I put it here so that the many of us, queer, crip, Mad, neurodivergent nurturers who desire this parenthood can know we're not alone./10

To have this all explode within me as we watch Roe v. Wade crumble is so much. Abortion access keeps me alive. Bc I do not trust doctors to actually know what is "medically necessary," when a pregnancy would endanger my life, because they have been wrong many times before. /9

I am exhausted by the lack of imagination. From K, who couldn't imagine with me new forms of parenthood and good, good love.

From parts of my community who only think of parenting in the nuclear family model and thus as something to dismantle or destroy in all forms. /8

Patriarchy tells me my body is abhorrent for how it cannot keep a fetus alive.

Many of my peers in crip & queer spaces have told me I am wrong for wanting this in the first place. That I've purchased an oppressive dream without asking why I dreamed it in the first place. /7

Yesterday, when K left me with no warning, announcing from nowhere that this fantasy, this imagined future, was more sustaining to him than the love we'd built between us, I was ashamed. Ashamed I couldn't bear his children & ashamed for wanting a child from my body so badly. /6

I will admit that sometimes I wake in the the night sobbing, visited in sleep by an imagined child I have wanted for decades to hold.

That grief will remain, & in many ways, I cherish it. It reminds me of how I can love others with what is so powerfully nurturing in me./5

I love myself for how I have found the alternatives. How I have found queer, crip, divergent ways of parenting in the world. It has helped to close the wound. I cannot have children--fostering and adopting is likely out of the question, too, given my queerness and Madness. /4

My desire to parent, especially to mother, has informed most of my life. It is why I have chosen the work I do. It is why I choose community care & activism. Why I teach. Why I nannied and worked with youth for years. Why I worked in suicide prevention. Why I love ferociously. /3

I am not infertile technically. I can get pregnant (I know because of a past miscarriage), but my body cannot carry a pregnancy to term. My body also cannot survive the hormones needed to harvest my ovaries.

I have wanted to be a mother my entire life. I have craved it. /2

TW: Ableism, fertility 
I have been carrying so much shame the past 24 hours, & I need to tell you all what happened so I can set it down.

K left me.

Because I cannot have biological children.

I am devastated. He is the 5th to leave me bc of this, but the first I loved. 🧵

We're given the choice of "either or" and not "both." But if I have managed both, in messy, creative, resilient ways for my bodymind with the help of my beloved community, then we can absolutely manage it for each other. The choice is always a false one.

So many of the ableist spaces that create this conflict (not access friction--that's a fact of life) operate on manufacturing scarcity. Scarce space, resources, etc. They're not conducive to community building, in all its messiness & wobbly flexibility to make room for each other

The nondisabled solution to access friction is to create conflict between crips seeking access. We're sometimes good at refusing this, sometimes not. White crips especially imo struggle to refuse the bait.

But I genuinely believe constructive community conversations can help us.

We don't talk about access friction within the same bodymind enough. Or access friction generally (in a constructive way)

@BaileyGeePoetry Fall before this, a stranger tried to pull me up this way and at least I could delight in his horror when my shoulder popped out of socket. And his equal horror when I put it back in like nbd. That was in the summer and my arm is still fucked.

I needed a chance to catalog potential injuries, make sure standing at all was even safe, and equalize my vertigo and dysautonomia

My arms are also very easily pulled out of socket

Even in an accident, don’t touch people without consent, especially when they’re able to give it.

Disabled people especially often have specific needs when being helped off the ground or from sitting.

I just got knocked over in the grocery store and several people rushed over, touched me without my consent, and began tugging me to my feet.

DONT DO THIS.

PSA:

WHEN SOMEONE FALLS YOU DO NOT HELP THEM UP BY THEIR HAND.

REPEAT: Unless the person you’re helping is a weightlifter who has not skipped leg or arm day, do not help them up by their hand.

Ask. How. They. Need. Help.
Do not touch them, esp. disabled people without consent.

If there's a strike, mobilize community supports for carpools, food deliveries, & other needs. Do as best you can. Talk about how we're trapped relying on exploitative companies like Uber and Amazon to survive. Get angry about it. Be creative. Refuse to side with capitalism. /fin

You know who doesn't treat me like shit? My grocery delivery drivers. They're also paid a much higher wage. (Still not a living wage for YVR).
This long thread is to say: labour justice is disability justice. Choose solidarity whenever possible. Even if it's imperfect & messy./10

As much as he was an objective asshole, I blame Uber Eats and all the other gig economy bullshit. Rushed, underpaid, and often exploited by both Uber and delivery recipients, he had no reason to treat me decently.  This is a regular interaction with these companies. /9

The incident ended with me injured after I slipped and soaked in rain. He had threatened to cancel my order if I didn't come outside without my cane to meet him. He was soaked, too, & I don't know how his next delivery went after getting turned around trying to find my building/8

I felt for him. I really really did. But this was the only safe food I could get today between my disabilities and current cash situation. The power we wielded over each other at that moment made it so messy.

(Disclosure: he became so abusive, I did have to file a report.) /7

On the phone today, my driver (between ableist abuse and expletives) kept repeating he had another order in his car as he struggled to locate my place. His tips and rating on the app were at stake as mine and that other order cooled. Especially in classist Vancouver. /6

But workers we encounter are punished for taking the ✨time✨ it takes to assist disabled people adequately. Bus drivers are monitored for timeliness, adherence to time tables that punish any delay. Ride-share drivers' cars aren't protected. They are always being rushed along. /5

These daily encounters make up a lot of visible ableism, but the more privileged sides of disability twitter have often struggled to choose solidarity with worker struggles (see the recent safe foods debacle with the Kellogg's strike). /4

Today I had an awful experience with a driver who endangered my safety. It escalated when I disclosed my disability.

Disability Twitter is full of examples like this. Videos of denied rides for wheelchair & service dog users. Denied food deliveries. Refusal to lower bus ramps./3

Delivery drivers, bus drivers, and tons of other service workers provide absolutely essential services to disabled people, ✨especially✨ during a global pandemic. I get groceries & other food delivered. Those delivery drivers (even the ableist, cruel ones) have kept me alive. /2

I genuinely believe that service workers (esp. gig workers) like delivery or bus drivers would be far less ableist if they were paid a living wage. If their work didn't endanger their safety & exploit them, I think it'd be so much easier to treat disabled clients kindly. /1

These partially formed thoughts emerge from my grief over the disaster in the English Channel. How whiteness can look away so easily, returning to these harrowing sites of violence for pleasure--a pleasure rooted in able-bodied supremacy--over and over again. I hate it. /fin

How white notions of exercise and sport reinforce systems of oppression because of the places they're mapped onto, the running trails, bike paths, scenic roads--all of it is so enmeshed in white supremacist ideas of "health" and "wellness" that are so damaging. /5

Recreation in urban planning and public health is a key site where ableism and healthism emerge as justifications for relocating, segregating, or outright destroying communities deemed "unsightly" in order to prioritize the "health" and "fitness" of white people. /4

Kitsilano and its beaches, parks, and museums were once a Sḵwx̱wú7mesh reserve that settlers nefariously stole under threat of police violence.

Roads built through North Shore reserves explicitly for access to recreational "advantages" of North & West Vancouver. /3

I think about recreation spaces in the Lower Mainland of British Columbia, too. Stanley Park, whose Indigenous residents at X̱wáýx̱way met settler violence in the late 19th century, developers demolishing their village for Park Drive. Or Pacific Spirit, stolen Indigenous land. /2

I want to write a whole ass book about ableist/healthist obsession with "recreation" and the white western rec spaces that map over sites of extraordinary violence. The migrant catastrophe in the English Channel comes to mind. 27 dead on a waterway swam for sport by others./1

The most violently marginalized, disempowered in our societies know the most abt how power disables & punishes disability (among other things). They are also the most gaslit, silenced members of our communities. Yet they hold the roadmap to our collective liberations. /fin

The interrelatedness of our oppression(s) and the oppressive power structures that imperil us does not mean they are the same. We have to listen for difference in the interrelation. How do these exps of violence change how we related to what appear to be our similarities? /9

If we centre privileged exps, we cannot dismantle what was actually formed to control the most marginalized. We aren't reading the instruction booklet right. Our hubris, a vestige of privilege, means we read it halfway & toss it aside. And we come up with the wrong answers./8

Straight size people exp ableism formed in the crucible of fatphobia (also rooted in antiBlackness) but attenuate by thinness. Cis people exp disabling violence formed to control trans people but mitigated. Our relationships to privilege change & mitigate our exp with violence./7

That violence THEN gets turned/expanded against others, but mitigated by privilege. I may exp ableism/violence formed in our society to control, dispossess, and eliminate Black people, immigrants, and Indigenous people, BUT that ableism is attenuated by my white settlerness. /6

with *all* ableism being *like* (or worse than🤮) anti-Blackness (for ex), which, I hope we've learned, erases the exps of Black disabled people. In fact, what much of this research tries to describe is that ableism & disabling violence forms against the most marginalized./5

Powerful research by folks like @DrSamiSchalk, @JayDolmage, and a number of others show how ableism & disabling violence are formed in anti-Blackness, anti-queer/transness, xenophobia, settler colonialism, imperialism, fatphobia, etc. But sometimes this gets conflated /4

I think Dr. Raibmon's advice to distrust our sureness in our "intellectual ability, empathetic ear, or good intentions," to not allow ourselves to fall prey to our overconfidence, and to listen for difference, produces the most powerful solidarities. It requires deep humility. /3

My advisor, Dr. Paige Raibmon, writes in her introduction to Sliammon elder Elsie Paul's _Written As I Remember It_ writes of how we, non-Indigenous people, ought to read the narrative(s) from Paul. I have wrestled with this mightily during my graduate degree. But, /2 https://t.co/flFZWHNcVv

There are words for love in this language, too. I am so grateful for them. For how I have been taught the curve of them on my tongue, their punctuation and heft.

There is no love like Mad crip love. No tether, touch, or tenderness like it. I am so glad I have known so much.

To hold one another above water for just a little longer, because the stars are out and the sky is glorious here. Look up.

I do not have to lie about not drowning. About bleeding, spiraling, or dislocation. Pain is a language we speak so well. We have learned how to love in it.

We are so far from perfect lovers that our dislocation from perfection allows us such transformative modes of accountability to one another out of deep, abiding love. We don’t love with an aim of perfect. We aim to press palms against wounds. To pull rip cords. To relocate joints

That I must repair to be cared for.

Crip care takes me as I am. As I am or not at all. I do not have to heal to be loved. There is no glue or scab or straining muscles holding me together so it is easier for others to love me.

The best of our love offers the space for ✨being✨

& this is why I think I must leave academia. To trust my/our knowledge, I have to refuse expertise. To refuse expertise in academia is nearly impossible. It is contaminating. Others may find it possible. I am too unfocused & gullible. If I can refuse power, I think I must./fin

When we speak to one another, when we self diagnose, describe symptoms and trauma, speak to our bent, ruptured, broken, transformative world-making, it is with trust of being heard. Expertise cannot listen. Trust can.

Maybe that is how we crips help break & remake the world. /6

I don’t want expertise in my community. That would mean wielding power over them/us, & that feels fundamentally at odds with how Mad crips do.

Maybe crip utopia & safety is where there is no such thing as expertise.

It is replaced with trust. Trust sutures us back together. /5

Sometimes we try to relocate this expertise back into these lacerated bodies and cultures by saying they/we are the experts of our own experiences.

But expertise is hegemonic, isn’t it? It’s totalizing. And my knowledge of self and community cannot ever be all-encompassing. /4

Part of why CDS critique of the medical model is so powerful is bc it describes the forcible removal of knowledge from disabled/aberrant/non-normative bodies and cultures (sometimes the literal cutting out of this knowledge) where it then becomes “expertise” in white hands. /3

This is why I refuse expertise. There is a lot of feminist discourse that battles imposter syndrome in academia by reinforcing notions of expertise as a concept, assuring marginalized folks we are experts of our exp. But expertise is an exercise in power, not knowledge. /2

Self reminder: I do know ✨a lot✨ abt what I study & worked hard to learn these things. But academia’s ethos of “never enough” grants expertise to power, not knowledge. I will never know enough (esp as nonnormative) to satisfy academia/our culture’s standards to speak at all. /1

THEY DO NONE OF THIS WITHOUT MY CONSENT

NONE of this is support they offer w/out knowing that 1) I need it and 2) I ✨want✨ it

Nondisabled allies: this is how you support us. All of this is central to crip community already. Learn from us. Material & consensual care only./fin

-make small decisions like what food to get, what brand to buy, which route to take when I ask them to
-give me rides to places
-buy my meds (only when asked)
-take out my recycling when I’m unwell
-offers funds for expensive necessities
-a whole lots more

-boss me around or treat me like a child
-patronise me
-assume what I need.

Because they’ve actually taken several months to learn from me, they DO:
-listen to me.
-carry heavy parcels for me
-help me keep socially distanced with people
-make phone calls for me /4

In essence, they took notes.

They DONT:
-ever touch my cane when I’m walking
-rush to open doors
-insist on navigating spaces for me
-stop me from doing chores/take over w/out asking
-tell me what I need to do/when I need to do it
-✨offer advice✨ for how to do things better /3

the soft, loving, but firm and emphatic talking to was immediately followed by a well thought out, tangible list of ways they’ve promised to help me reduce my workload. They had thought about what they can offer and had listened carefully to what is hard for me. /2

But it does hold space for how healing-the hard work I and my communities have done-belongs to us. We can love the ways we've healed, including our "responses." We can hold our responses with immense tenderness & compassion. They are proof we survived. We are allowed to love that

My past trauma speaks in the present moment in bizarre, complex, & incoherent ways. It can be difficult, unwieldy, scary, but it can also be joyful, loving, luminous.

The ways I've healed aren't universally good or bad. This isn't toxic positivity--not making trauma "worth it."

And what is a "trauma response" for one can be an intentional or instinctive act for another that does not arise from trauma.

Something being a "trauma response" (or the deep speaking of residual past trauma in our present) does not hold universal meaning.

Oh my lord, y'all. Not everything is a trauma response. Our whole beings are not made up of only responding to trauma. These kinds of totalizing statements are what communities have fought against forever. Even responses to trauma, too, can be sources of joy and wholeness.

Yes this is a subtweet. Yes it's about the blog I did for Active History about pandemic academic ableism. Yes I hate academic drama.

If I make a critique of an institution or structure, that does not mean I hate everyone in that institution/structure. In fact, deeply intimate and loving acts had to come from people within the institution in order for me to survive. That is how I live to make the critique.

Possibilities that lie in sharp contrast to my experiences of the past few years. To have days like this is to see with utter clarity that it does not have to be this way. I and my kin and all of us so brutalized by this place never had to experience this violence.

It reminds me of the profound possibilities that lie in academia to do good in the world. To be a good place where people can and do feel whole, valued, and supported. Where people can show up as their whole selves to do world-making-changing-crafting-shattering work.

I'm having one of those days full of what I love in academia: smooth writing, deep engagement with historical materials, stimulating conversations & validation from (rightly) esteemed scholars, & multivalent/directional support from peers.

It makes the grief of leaving acute.

We lived in community among orchards and living, breathing things. We were loved and safe when we were protected within community. We were always whole, always beautiful, even in our deviance and startling difference.
In life, we laid in the dew-damp grass and looked at the stars

And it speaks to how fundamentally different our lived experiences are to how we are actually treated culturally. When we, crip, Mad freaks, appear in the cultural canon, we are objects of fascination. People become voyeurs when they look upon our bodies.

But we were loved.

"Two-Headed Calf" by Laura Gilpin (Img incl alt text)

I spent most of my life thinking these experiences were normal & that everyone was victimized similarly. With the revelation of my diagnosis, I'm realizing this is not the case. And I think we need space to talk about it. Safely, in our language.

TW sexual assault, grooming

I was not expecting to vaguely out myself this morning, but this needed to come out. We millennials encountered a strange sometimes thrilling, sometimes traumatizing world on the early internet. Especially queer & neurodivergent kids.

TW: sexual assault, grooming

The language to articulate our difference and thus our needs, is CRITICAL to preventing the catastrophic epidemic of sexual violence against us.
Parents' internalized ableism about their kids has real consequences for the violence we have to survive.

TW: sexual assault, grooming

This is why I am ENRAGED when I see parents withholding their kids' diagnoses from them.

83% of disabled women are sexually assaulted in their lifetimes.

As much as 90% of intellectually disabled AFAB folks experience sexual violence.

TW: sexual assault, grooming

I was derided as "attention seeking" by everyone around me and so I learned to smother those impulses and satisfy them in private (i.e. dangerous virtual spaces) and later with predatory men in my local community.

TW: sexual assault, grooming

& it only reinforces to me the power of diagnosis for neurodivergent kids when it's given to us as a language to describe our exp.

I didn't know I was critically vulnerable to this exploitation. I just had a brain compulsively seeking connection.

TW: sexual assault, grooming

I know for a fact that queer kids/youth of my generation were especially vulnerable to this as well. Isolated kids are vulnerable kids.
I'm certain this is still happening today. Not in the same chat rooms and message boards as before, but elsewhere.

It took less than a week for me, a disabled graduate student and academic labourer, to contract COVID while back on campus.

I'm sure this is institutionally acceptable. I hope it isn't for you. I hope my suffering and risk and fear isn't "worth it" for this haphazard return.

I hope folks reading this will honour the pain and rage and fear and grief that goes into this thread. This is not my most researched thread or best thought out. But there is something to the fact that I am on round two, a disabled queer, when my nondisabled family is unscathed.

And I live in a place that's doing relatively "well" (although the utter lack of transparency by institutions like UBC and BCCDC are obscuring exactly how far "well" extends.) 

Policy has failed me, in my opinion & experience these past 2 years.

I can't believe I'm back here.

I did everything to protect myself. I kept up with the guidance. I masked, I distanced, I vaccinated. I've been meticulous this entire pandemic.

And yet.

Here I am, with round two.

I can't have it confirmed even because I'm too sick to make it to testing with my disabled body.

Public health orders have rarely explicitly mentioned disabled and vulnerable folks aside from those in long term care, carceral settings whose abuse is finally seeing daylight because of this gods' forsaken pandemic.

We are forgotten and rarely considered in published guidance.

BC returned to in person learning before approving third doses for clinically ext vulnerable folks. Still have only approved them for a tiny pop, continuing their eugenicist policy that excludes *most* disabled people, as it did in early vaccinations.

https://t.co/jhgaMZibII

Seeing my dad scared when I told him I likely have COVID again terrified me. I live in Canada. Family in US. I've had COVID twice now, the only one in my family.

Don't tell me disabled people haven't born the brunt of this catastrophe & the policy choices that have extended it.

Every time I prep for a workshop on how crip ethics conflict with academia's, I cry going over my notes. Like, they are so fundamentally opposed that sometimes it feels hopeless. How in holy hell do we reconcile these things? How to we create enough movement just to exist here?

Academic integrity, academic rigor, and meritocracy are not worth protecting.

They're certainly not worth your life's dedication, your health, or your peace of mind, let alone your soul.

Just choose community. You will prevent so much harm. https://t.co/VR5r8f2Y8Y

I don't have a good answer to this tension other than the long work of building beloved community where anti-masking is not tolerated. Where transformative justice and not further "cop shit" is what allows us to end ableism & other oppression. For now, I sit in the discomfort. /5

But it also fundamentally goes against my ethics as a disabled person to subject other disabled folks to surveillance and bureaucratic violence by the academy. This is extra labour disabled students will have to perform just to exist in the same space as nondisabled peers. /4

I am an immunocompromised educator and need masking to protect me right now. I don't have the social or labour capital to demand work from home (although I have received partial only because the individual prof I work for is fantastic).

I need my students to mask. /3

It benefits those with access to money, time, institutional knowledge, and social support.

It gives more power to codified surveillance mechanisms that harm disabled, especially BIPOC and queer, students. It is more surveillance when disability justice demands less. /2

A 🧵:
I don't have an answer to this concern, but I think it's important that we pay attention to the fact that universities (@UBC incl) are processing mask exemptions through the accommodations process pipeline.

This process already harms and benefits along oppressive lines. /1

We are still in crisis learning. Refuse to be an agent of harm against yourself and your students.

The pandemic isn't over. Our pedagogy must incorporate all we've learned in distance crisis learning as we return to in-person and navigate trauma and crisis together. /fin

There are also resources from BIPOC, queer, and other marginalized educators worth exploring. All of these alternative ways of knowing and learning and teaching are essential now. Please seek them out. 

I'll be posting a few below as I find them.

.@daniellelorenz and I worked to build the @TheCJDS Cripping Pandemic Learning resource that collects crip and UDL teaching resources for educators. It's a great starting point.

https://t.co/DFAcSrGyGA

So where do we go from here?

We build coalitions. We learn from one another. We share our pedagogies and build from the knowledge of marginalized educators and students.

Cross-solidarity now is essential in back to in-person crisis learning.

The pandemic isn't over. We and our students and the rest of our academic communities are at risk. 

Even if it were over, there is no reason we should return to how this place worked before. It didn't work for most of us before. Our efforts now can make it work in the future.

We have the chance to defend our students and ourselves by choosing different ethics, by choosing to return to a transformed academy rather than the white supremacist, colonial, ableist, racist, sexist space we've been forced to inhabit for so long. It starts in our classrooms.

It is more essential than ever that we refuse this pernicious suggestion. Pedagogies of care, crip ethics, UDL, and more, offer us the opportunity to continue to transform learning in higher education.

We must take this opportunity. We cannot continue to be agents of harm.

We are at risk of causing enormous harm to ourselves & our students if we buy the lie that education departments and universities are pushing: that it is time for business as usual.

Business as usual, the norms of before, were violent and are what helped manufacture this crisis.

The care, compassion, reflexivity, and flexibility that online learning of the past year required, is still ✨absolutely essential✨ because we are still wholly immersed in crisis learning. It wasn't online learning alone that required these things. It's crisis learning.

Returning to in-person learning for many of us has been/will be intense, re-traumatizing, and/or triggering. As much as our students and ourselves were in crisis during distance learning, we must also anticipate that new and old crises will follow us into the physical classroom.

Our students & ourselves as academic labourers could be facing yet more preventable upheaval & acute crisis in the coming months.

We, as educators, must plan for this. 

We must recognize that we (our students & ourselves) are traumatized & anticipate we will be re-traumatized.

In fact, this term might be even more crisis-laden than previous terms. This has the potential to be like spring 2020, except it will be entirely a crisis of our universities' own making through their choices that deprioritize human welfare in order to maintain financial margins.

We are still in crisis learning: a thread.

Universities might be forcing us back into in-person learning, but that in no way means we have exited crisis learning.

Crisis learning (pandemic learning) endures as long as the crisis. Not just when we're in distance/online learning.

I have also been told my entire life that the only people capable of taking care of me are people wholly unlike myself.

Both of these are lies.

We take care of us. We, the Mad, crip, disabled, neurodivergent are the best carers of us.

Do not let them tell you otherwise. /fin

These are both contrary to what medical professionals have told me my entire life. That my fatness was universally bad, harmful in every way, and something I must always be ashamed of, always engaged in trying to destroy it. /9

And made sure I did not feel the shame that so often follows for disabled folks when our first interventions post-event are from nondisabled people.

I immediately felt safe asking for care because of community. Because of crip community. Not bc I had nondisabled carers. /8

This cushioned my impact, protected my joints, muscles, and bones, and even protected my head from whacking the ground.

My fatness, ✨clinically speaking✨ kept me safe.

I will never get a doctor to admit to this, but it protects me as I pursue independent disabled life. /6

I also have brittle bones from a decade on steroids + other meds. This means falls can be easily catastrophic.

Tonight, I fell forward, onto my belly and breasts which took the brunt of the impact after I managed to avoid sticking all but one of my limbs out to catch myself. /5

First, it was survivable because I am fat.

Read that again.

This fall was survivable because I am fat.

I have a very brittle musculature, part of chronic hyper mobility and arthritis. My muscles turn to stone trying to hold my joints together. This means they tear easily. /4

I was immediately seen and helped to my feet, although not particularly safely considering I was winded and couldn’t communicate that I had arthritis to the folks. They were helpful and I was grateful.

This wasn’t survivable because of them, though. /3

Just clarification: white disabled people aren't victims of white supremacy. But we are affected by the historical formation of white supremacist institutions that now serve multiple oppressive purposes (see prisons/psychiatric incarceration for ex.). Just wanted to be clear.

Disability work requires anti-racist work. No white disabled person gets a pass. None. But our proximity to Power makes us reticent to do such work. That reticence is white supremacy. Destroy it. /fin

Standing behind your disability as a shield protecting you from doing the work of destroying these institutions is a cop out at best, intentional violence at worst. No disability makes you racist. It is learned, and we've certainly bought into it in the disability community. /3

The institutions made to harm BIPOC folks are gluttonous beasts that expand beyond those bounds and consume the deviant white people of society, too--poor, disabled, queer, etc.

But even if white supremacy only harmed BIPOC folks, we should all be invested in destroying it. /2

If you think disabled (white) people can achieve any modicum of liberation without destroying white supremacy, you can get fucked

The violence of white supremacy disables us all.
But even if it didn't, all oppressions support the others.
White disabled people have work to do. /1

It just makes no sense especially when we’re all so gods damned traumatized? That Madness and traumatized mind-worlding is integral to our culture in chronic pain communities. Why have we as people allowed the pernicious suggestion that valid pain and insanity can’t coexist? /3

I know doctors require us to compartmentalize, but why do we continue that violence and ask it of one another? /2

I’ve experienced both the pain of psychotic hallucinations and the hallucinations involved with migraines and there is almost no discernible difference.

But I’m still asked in community to hold those experiences separately.

Chronic pain communities don’t welcome my Madness./1

@Cymru_Et_Canada personal *fault* but healing, to the best of our ability, is a community exercise and personal responsibility. Ending the cycle, in a sense, is our responsibility, since shame is a leaky thing. It doesn't stay contained in ourselves.
So, avoiding blame, but taking responsibility?

@Cymru_Et_Canada Ohh. No I totally get that. But I think we also have to recognize how our own shame, when we express it, has the potential to create more shame? Right? Like when fat people hate their bodies it can make other fat people hate their own too? But still holding that shame isn't /1

@Cymru_Et_Canada Yes. I think there are two ways shame moves where it's 1) primarily internal then 2) when the internal gets directed externally against others. For a lot of us, it stays internal, and that's a harder question to answer. But I know for me, my shame *is* about power and trauma.

This is such an important question to ask yourself to heal. To heal from all kinds of oppression. Shame is a pervasive tool of violent structures. What you are most ashamed of can often be what is most revolutionary about yourself. https://t.co/1dadeDAWsC
